ChatGPT said:

Got it! Let me answer both questions clearly and concretely, building on what we discussed.

1) About device_context when you have multiple device logs in log_story

Given your example, you have two devices' logs mixed inside the log_story array "wan_console" and "LAN_console".

How should device_context look then?

  • device_context is per device it describes the state and key info for a single device.

  • If multiple devices are involved, you should have a separate device_context for each device.

  • So your final LogContextObject should have something like:

json
"device_contexts": [
  {
    "device_name": "wan0",
    "last_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
    "last_command_status": "timeout",
    "last_log_line": "Device unreachable"
  },
  {
    "device_name": "lan0",
    "last_command": "...",
    "last_command_status": "...",
    "last_log_line": "..."
  }
]

Why?
Because each device is distinct. Collapsing multiple device logs into one device_context makes it ambiguous and less useful.

2) Where to put additional info like pexpect failure details, expected commands, code snippets, etc.?

This is crucial info for deep RCA and downstream AI/human understanding. Here's a recommended structure:

  • Create a dedicated field in LogContextObject called execution_context or interaction_context this can include stuff about the environment or session, e.g., pexpect interactions.

Example:

json
"execution_context": {
  "pexpect": {
    "expected_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
    "timeout": 30,
    "failure_type": "expect_timeout",
    "last_sent_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
    "last_received_output": [
      "Request timed out",
      "Device unreachable"
    ],
    "code_snippet": [
      "def connect_device():",
      "    child.sendline('ping 192.168.1.1')",
      "    child.expect('Request timed out')"
    ]
  }
}

Putting it all together a richer example LogContextObject

json
{
  "log_story": [
    {
      "source": "wan_console",
      "snippet": [
        ">> reboot",
        "<< rebooting device...",
        ">> ping 192.168.1.1",
        "<< Request timed out",
        ">> ifconfig wan0",
        "<< Device unreachable"
      ]
    },
    {
      "source": "lan_console",
      "snippet": [
        ">> reboot",
        "<< rebooting device...",
        ">> ping 192.168.1.1",
        "<< Request timed out",
        ">> ifconfig lan0",
        "<< Device unreachable"
      ]
    }
  ],
  "device_contexts": [
    {
      "device_name": "wan0",
      "last_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
      "last_command_status": "timeout",
      "last_log_line": "Device unreachable"
    },
    {
      "device_name": "lan0",
      "last_command": "ifconfig lan0",
      "last_command_status": "device unreachable",
      "last_log_line": "Device unreachable"
    }
  ],
  "execution_context": {
    "pexpect": {
      "expected_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
      "timeout": 30,
      "failure_type": "expect_timeout",
      "last_sent_command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
      "last_received_output": [
        "Request timed out",
        "Device unreachable"
      ],
      "code_snippet": [
        "def connect_device():",
        "    child.sendline('ping 192.168.1.1')",
        "    child.expect('Request timed out')"
      ]
    }
  }
}

Why this helps?

  • Separation of concerns: log_story is raw or lightly processed log snippets, grouped by source.

  • device_contexts summarise each device's last state info, commands, and critical lines concise and structured for easy consumption.

  • execution_context holds orchestration-level data (pexpect session info, command expectations, failure modes, relevant code), important for both AI and human analysts.

Final notes

  • This design allows your AI model or human analysts to quickly see both the big picture (all device states), the detailed logs (for context), and the orchestration/failure environment (pexpect failures, code involved).

  • You avoid redundancy while keeping the important info structured and accessible.

  • When AI consumes this, you can vectorize log_story text snippets, encode categorical device_context fields, and pass execution_context flags to guide inference.

You said:
so you mena the log_story should only have relivant device or application specific logs wrt notng else ????
ChatGPT said:

Yes exactly. The log_story should contain only the most relevant, contextually necessary logs related to the suspected failure device or application specific and not everything from the entire dump.

Why?

  1. Relevance = Focus
    You're trying to tell a story around the failure, not replay the entire novel. The AI or human analyst doesn't need thousands of lines just the right 2050 lines that matter.

  2. Avoid Noise
    Including unrelated logs from other devices (e.g., FXS logs when WAN failed) may confuse your AI model or overwhelm a human.

  3. Efficiency
    The smaller and more focused your log_story, the easier it is to:

    • Embed it (for LLMs or vector search)

    • Display it on a UI

    • Train AI models effectively

What should go into log_story?

For each involved component (device or app):

IncludeExamples
Failure logsException trace, timeout message
Command & responses>> ping 192.168.1.1, << timeout
Snippets before failure1020 lines max
Snippets after failure510 lines if available
Logs from related sourcesIf multiple devices interact (e.g., WAN & LAN), show both sides
Don't includeLogs from unrelated modules, background daemons, or passing test cases

Example

Good log_story:

json
"log_story": [
  {
    "source": "wan_console",
    "snippet": [
      ">> reboot",
      "<< rebooting...",
      ">> ping 192.168.1.1",
      "<< timeout",
      ">> ifconfig",
      "<< no IP assigned"
    ]
  },
  {
    "source": "wan_app_log",
    "snippet": [
      "Error: WAN interface failed to initialize",
      "Traceback (most recent call last): ...",
      "File 'wan_lib.py', line 50, in bring_up_wan"
    ]
  }
]

Bad log_story:

json
"log_story": [
  {
    "source": "wan_console",
    "snippet": [ /* 200 lines of all device init logs */ ]
  },
  {
    "source": "fxs_console",
    "snippet": [ ">> dialtone", "<< OK" ]
  },
  {
    "source": "cmts_log",
    "snippet": [ "Nothing to see here..." ]
  }
]

Tip:

Your analyzers job is to extract these focused log blocks filter, trim, score relevance and build this story. Dont dump everything.

Think: "What would a smart human want to see to debug this?"

Would you like a utility function that takes raw logs and auto-constructs a focused log_story from scoring logic or markers (e.g., time proximity to failure, command-response pairs)? I can help with that too

Where does this info come from?

  • "device_contexts" constructed by your analyzer by scoring logs per device

  • "execution_context" can be extracted by wrapping the test/automation framework (e.g., hooks in your automation that expose what pexpect sent, expected, and saw)

If you dont have automation instrumentation for this, leave execution_context blank or partial.

FieldExtracted from

ChatGPT said:

Great question this is exactly where structured execution context helps bridge the gap between low-level logs and high-level RCA storytelling.

You're asking:

"If the app failed with a stack trace and not a pexpect error, what should execution_context contain?"

First, What Is execution_context?

Its not just for pexpect.

Its a general block meant to capture the system-under-test + orchestrator's flow that led to the failure in structured steps.

That includes:

  • Function invocations (with ordering)

  • Where the failure occurred (stack trace)

  • Whether device interaction was attempted

  • Where the last known successful checkpoint was

Example Use Case

Lets say:

  1. Your app log contains a Python stack trace:

    plaintext
    File "wan_lib.py", line 120, in connect_device
File "device_comm.py", line 75, in send_command
TimeoutError: No prompt received from device

  2. Theres no explicit pexpect log. But your automation layer uses pexpect under the hood inside send_command().

Then your execution_context could look like this:

json
"execution_context": {
  "flow_trace": [
    {
      "function": "connect_device",
      "file": "wan_lib.py",
      "line": 120,
      "status": "called"
    },
    {
      "function": "send_command",
      "file": "device_comm.py",
      "line": 75,
      "status": "failed",
      "error": "TimeoutError: No prompt received from device"
    }
  ],
  "stack_summary": {
    "top_function": "send_command",
    "exception": "TimeoutError",
    "message": "No prompt received from device"
  },
  "pexpect_summary": {
    "used": true,
    "last_command_sent": "ping 192.168.1.1",
    "expected_output_pattern": "wan#",
    "timeout_seconds": 30,
    "failure_type": "expect_timeout",
    "last_buffer_received": [
      ""
    ]
  }
}

Breakdown of What Each Part Means:

1. "flow_trace"

A chronological list of function calls and their outcomes like breadcrumbs.
Helps the AI or analyst see how the logic moved through the code.

2. "stack_summary"

A simplified high-level stack trace showing where it crashed and why.

  • Helps correlate with rule-based patterns (e.g., every time send_command fails with TimeoutError, it's usually due to device not responding.)

3. "pexpect_summary"

This section exists only if pexpect was involved.

Even if pexpect didn't raise an error directly, if your app was using it under the hood (like send_command()), it helps to mention what was expected vs what actually came back (even if blank).

If There Was NO pexpect or Device

Lets say it was a pure app-level failure nothing to do with device, just bad logic.

Then execution_context would look like:

json
"execution_context": {
  "flow_trace": [
    {
      "function": "validate_config",
      "file": "provisioner.py",
      "line": 45,
      "status": "called"
    },
    {
      "function": "generate_dns_config",
      "file": "dns_util.py",
      "line": 22,
      "status": "failed",
      "error": "ValueError: Invalid DNS structure"
    }
  ],
  "stack_summary": {
    "top_function": "generate_dns_config",
    "exception": "ValueError",
    "message": "Invalid DNS structure"
  },
  "pexpect_summary": {
    "used": false
  }
}

How Do You Build This?

The analyzer is responsible for:

  • Parsing stack traces

  • Extracting function + file + line info

  • Determining failure cause (e.g., from exception message)

  • Optionally tagging involvement of pexpect/device

This gives a pre-processed, human-and-ML friendly view of the failure.

Final Summary

SectionUse
flow_traceTells the story of function calls like breadcrumbs leading to failure
stack_summaryWhere exactly did it crash and why?
pexpect_summaryOnly exists if device interaction via pexpect is involved (even if error was raised by app code)

plaintext

json
"execution_context": {

      "Request timed out"
    ]

}

Lets break it down:

KeyPurpose
flow_traceEven if no Python functions were called, the test itself is a logical unit it's your top-level "function".
test_summaryTreats the test like a "function" that failed contains enough context to reproduce or understand
captured_outputThis is your main clue the logs you saw on the test terminal
pexpect_summaryIf device interaction was part of the test, extract the failed command and pattern

json
"related_device": "wan0"

You said:
so this execution_context will have variable key data ,, would it be a problem or not like it would be just like a execution_context:{} now {} can have any structure , baed on the log wrt ?
ChatGPT said:

Yes, youre absolutely right and youve nailed a subtle but important design decision here.

TL;DR:

Yes, execution_context will be semi-structured:
It will always exist as a dictionary, but its internal keys may vary depending on:

  • The type of failure (stack_trace, pytest_failure, pexpect_timeout, etc.)

  • The analyzer's understanding of the situation

  • The availability of captured metadata

And thats not a problem, if you handle it the right way.

Why it's OK for execution_context to be variable

  • Log formats and failure modes are inherently heterogeneous sometimes you have a traceback, sometimes a test failure, sometimes just pexpect timing out.

  • Trying to enforce a fixed schema would either:

    • Be too rigid and throw out useful data

    • Or lead to tons of meaningless null/None/empty fields

Instead, we treat execution_context as a flexible envelope, where only the relevant keys are present per analyzer and scenario.

How to design for that (Python / JSON / Schema-safe)

Option 1: Python TypedDict with optional fields

python
from typing import TypedDict, Literal, Optional, List

class FlowTrace(TypedDict, total=False):
    function: str
    file: str
    line: int
    status: Literal["called", "failed", "passed"]
    error: Optional[str]

class StackSummary(TypedDict, total=False):
    top_function: str
    exception: str
    message: str

class TestSummary(TypedDict, total=False):
    test_name: str
    file: str
    line: int
    result: str
    assertion: str
    message: str

class PexpectSummary(TypedDict, total=False):
    used: bool
    last_command_sent: str
    expected_output_pattern: Optional[str]
    timeout_seconds: Optional[int]
    failure_type: Optional[str]
    last_buffer_received: Optional[List[str]]

class ExecutionContext(TypedDict, total=False):
    flow_trace: List[FlowTrace]
    stack_summary: StackSummary
    test_summary: TestSummary
    captured_output: dict
    pexpect_summary: PexpectSummary

This lets you safely access only the keys you expect per failure mode, and skip others.

Option 2: JSON Schema

For tools outside Python, define a flexible schema where keys are optional:

json
{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "flow_trace": { "type": "array", "items": { /* etc */ } },
    "stack_summary": { "type": "object" },
    "test_summary": { "type": "object" },
    "pexpect_summary": { "type": "object" },
    "captured_output": { "type": "object" }
  },
  "additionalProperties": false
}

Bonus: Include a context_type or failure_mode key

You could even make this explicit by tagging the context like:

json
"execution_context": {
  "context_type": "pytest_failure",  // or "stack_trace", or "pexpect_error"
  ...
}

This makes downstream processing more robust.

Human & AI-Friendly

This approach lets:

  • Humans quickly recognize what happened (from relevant fields only)

  • ML models focus only on available, useful info

  • You scale your system across many failure types

In Summary

ConcernSolution
Variable keys inside execution_context Acceptable and expected
Possible mess or inconsistency Avoided by using TypedDicts / schemas with optional fields
Downstream safety Ensure contracts between analyzers and consumers define expected patterns
Futureproofing Can easily extend with new failure types

This JSON you shared is a fantastic example of a rich, structured context object after AI/analyzer inference that can be used downstream (human or ML/RCA pipeline). Let me break down and explain why its well-designed and how it answers your concerns, with some notes and practical insights:

Breakdown of Your Context Object

1. summary

  • High-level fault description (exception type, error message).

  • root_frame could be empty or filled when a stack trace is available.

  • blame_chain could represent the chain of suspected causes (empty here, but good to keep for future).

Why this matters: Provides a concise, easily digestible top-level RCA summary. Humans and AI can quickly understand the core issue.

2. tags

  • Keywords for quick classification and filtering: "wan", "timeout", "device_error", "pexpect".

Why this matters: Useful for search, filtering, and initial triaging without parsing the entire story.

3. log_story

  • Logs organized by source (device console, boardfarm app logs).

  • Each story chunk has a label and a context_ref (helps relate logs to code or events).

  • Time-stamped logs that include input commands and device/app responses.

Why this matters:
This is your evidence or detailed narrative. Its not redundant with the summary or device context because:

  • It contains raw or minimally processed logs.

  • It preserves chronological and contextual clues.

  • Enables deep dive when needed by humans or models.

4. device_context

  • Per-device status snapshot, last command run, and response.

  • Reflects the devices operational context as inferred or known.

Why this matters:
It abstracts key device state info thats relevant for root cause (e.g., WAN is offline, last reboot command sent but no prompt).
It complements the log story by providing a distilled device state summary useful for fast inference or alerting.

5. execution_context

  • Detailed info about test flow, failures, and pexpect interaction.

  • Includes structured test results, captured CLI output, and pexpect failure summaries.

Why this matters:
This is your technical diagnostic layer, crucial for debugging complex issues.
It captures dynamic runtime info and test/interaction context that logs or device state alone dont convey.

6. possible_causes

  • A list of likely root cause hypotheses extracted or inferred.

Why this matters:
Turns raw data into actionable insights for humans or automation, closing the gap between evidence and conclusion.

7. analyzer_info

  • Metadata about who/what produced this analysis.

Why this matters: For traceability, ownership, and versioning.

Why This Structure Works & Practical Takeaways

  • No redundancy or confusion: Each part has a clear purpose:

    • summary = what happened?

    • tags = quick classifiers

    • log_story = raw evidence in context

    • device_context = distilled device snapshot

    • execution_context = detailed interaction/test info

    • possible_causes = final hypotheses

  • Flexible and scalable: You can add more fields or new failure types without breaking existing consumers.

  • Supports AI & human use:

    • AI models can consume embeddings or text from log_story + structured info from device_context and execution_context for inference.

    • Humans can read the summary and drill down into logs and context as needed.

  • Realistic example: The presence of pexpect info, CLI commands, time-stamps, and test data shows youre covering real-world diagnostic complexity, not just toy examples.

A Lightened Mood Wrap-up

Imagine your analyzer is like Sherlock Holmes:

  • log_story = the full crime scene and witness statements, messy but rich.

  • device_context = the state of the suspects room, neat and telling.

  • execution_context = the sequence of events on the night, with timing and alibis.

  • summary = Sherlocks final verdict, concise but precise.

  • possible_causes = his best theories on who did it and why.

AI is your Watson, helping Sherlock sift clues and form hypotheses faster but it still needs all the pieces in the right place.

ChatGPT said:

Great question! Lets dissect whether all these fields are necessary or some might be redundant and how to keep the context object lean but complete.

Quick summary of fields you have:

FieldPurposeMust-have?Notes on potential redundancy or necessity
summaryHigh-level RCA overview (exception, error message, blame chain)YesEssential for quick understanding; not redundant, it's the result of analysis.
tagsKeywords for categorizationYes*Very useful for filtering and quick triage; can be autogenerated.
log_storyRaw/contextual logs from various sourcesYesCritical evidence base; no redundancy with summary or device_context because its raw info.
device_contextSnapshot of device status & last commandYesProvides distilled device state, complements logs with summary of device health & last action.
execution_contextTest flow, command execution, and pexpect detailsDependsImportant for debugging complex interactive tests or automated flows; can be optional if your use case doesnt include automated test contexts.
possible_causesHypothesized root causesYes*Very useful for human/AI downstream consumption; can be generated or updated as analysis evolves.
analyzer_infoMetadata about analyzer sourceOptionalUseful for traceability but not strictly necessary for every output.

Are some fields redundant or overlapping?

  • Summary vs Execution Context:

    • summary is the final RCA outcome concise and human-readable.

    • execution_context is detailed runtime info test results, CLI interactions, etc.
      These are complementary, not redundant. You want both because summary doesnt contain low-level traces, and execution_context doesnt contain high-level RCA.
      Only skip execution_context if you have no complex interactive test or runtime info.

  • Device Context vs Log Story:

    • device_context abstracts device state and last actions as key-value pairs.

    • log_story contains raw logs and CLI snippets around failure events.
      They serve different needs: device_context is a distilled snapshot, log_story is detailed evidence. Not redundant.
      If your log_story is extremely comprehensive and always perfectly parsed, device_context might be derivable, but it's best to keep for quick access.

  • Tags vs Summary vs Possible Causes:

    • tags are short keywords.

    • summary is descriptive.

    • possible_causes list candidate faults.
      They serve distinct purposes in filtering, explanation, and hypothesis generation.

When can you prune or merge?

  • If you have no automated testing or pexpect interaction, execution_context can be omitted or left empty.

  • If your logs are always fully parsed and device states always derivable from logs (rare in messy real environments), you could consider skipping device_context but thats risky and makes downstream processing slower.

  • If you want minimal data for quick triage only, you could keep just summary + tags + possible_causes and trim logs, but you lose detailed evidence for investigation.

Practical advice:

  • Keep summary, log_story, device_context, possible_causes as core fields. They form a balanced package: what happened, evidence, device state, and hypotheses.

  • Add execution_context only if you run complex tests or need rich interactive flow data.

  • Use analyzer_info for auditability but dont expect downstream RCA to rely on it.

Example minimal vs full context object

Minimal:

json
{
  "summary": {...},
  "tags": [...],
  "log_story": [...],
  "device_context": {...},
  "possible_causes": [...]
}

Full:

json
{
  "summary": {...},
  "tags": [...],
  "log_story": [...],
  "device_context": {...},
  "execution_context": {...},
  "possible_causes": [...],
  "analyzer_info": {...}
}

Lighthearted analogy:

  • Summary = The verdict.

  • Log story = The full court transcript.

  • Device context = The suspect's mood board.

  • Execution context = The timeline of events on the night.

  • Possible causes = Detectives theories on motive and opportunity.

  • Tags = The headline news tags.

  • Analyzer info = The detectives badge number.

You wouldnt skip the verdict or the transcript, but the badge number can be optional.

if flow_trace: list[FlowTrace] stack_summary: StackSummary if flow_trace is there why stacksummary is there , any specific reason or tis just an assumptions ?
ChatGPT said:

Good catch! Lets clarify the difference and why both might coexist, or if its redundant.

What is typically meant by:

  • flow_trace (list of FlowTrace):
    A detailed sequence of function calls, method invocations, or steps leading up to the failure. Think of it like a step-by-step execution path or call stack over time.
    Each FlowTrace item might include: function name, file, line number, status, maybe even timestamps or intermediate errors.

  • stack_summary (StackSummary):
    Usually a condensed snapshot of the error stack trace at the point of failure the top few frames, exception type, and message.
    Its a focused summary view of the stack trace to quickly see where exactly the failure originated.

Why have both?

  • flow_trace can be longer and more detailed, showing the full execution flow often useful for deep debugging, reconstructing the entire call journey or test flow.

  • stack_summary is a concise extraction showing only the key frames and exception info that define the failure point easier for quick inspection or reporting.

Is it redundant?

  • Sometimes, yes if your flow_trace already contains a full detailed call stack with all info, the stack_summary could be seen as a "highlighted" subset.

  • But many systems keep both for flexibility:

    • Use stack_summary for fast RCA overview and display (e.g., UI dashboards, reports).

    • Use flow_trace for in-depth forensic analysis when needed.

Example:

json
{
  "stack_summary": {
    "exception_type": "TimeoutError",
    "message": "Device did not respond",
    "frames": [
      {"file": "wan_lib.py", "function": "connect_device", "line": 120},
      {"file": "device_comm.py", "function": "send_command", "line": 75}
    ]
  },
  "flow_trace": [
    {
      "function": "setup_network",
      "file": "test_setup.py",
      "line": 45,
      "status": "passed"
    },
    {
      "function": "connect_device",
      "file": "wan_lib.py",
      "line": 120,
      "status": "failed",
      "error": "TimeoutError"
    },
    {
      "function": "send_command",
      "file": "device_comm.py",
      "line": 75,
      "status": "failed"
    }
  ]
}

  • Here stack_summary quickly shows the core failure frames and exception.

  • flow_trace gives a broader context on the test or call flow.

TL;DR

  • Keep both if you want:

    • Fast failure summary (stack_summary)

    • Full execution story (flow_trace)

  • Drop stack_summary if you think flow_trace already covers everything clearly, or vice versa.

Look for command blocks after thatEverything after prompt is usable interaction
Repeated prompts = stuck/timeoutUse to flag login issues

ChatGPT said:

Excellent and super realistic question you're hitting exactly the sort of ambiguity that makes log analysis non-trivial.

You're describing two key challenges:

Problem A: Misinterpreting Prompts (False Boundaries)

When scanning in reverse, you hit a prompt after command output. If you're not careful, you may assume this was an idle prompt, no command, but in fact, a command did run before it.

Problem B: Silent Failures or Partial Output

Some commands (like tcpdump, or custom tooling) dont return output, or get interrupted (e.g., TIMEOUT, device reboot, network cut), and no prompt is returned.

Goal

Design a prompt-aware log segmenter that:

  • Correctly identifies command blocks

  • Deals with prompt ambiguities

  • Handles missing outputs or delayed prompts

  • Works well for downstream story extraction

Step-by-Step: Resilient Device Log Segmenter

1. Forward scan preferred

Unless proven otherwise, always scan forward (not reverse) to maintain the natural causal flow:

plaintext
[prompt]  [command]  [output]  [next prompt]

Example:

plaintext
13:00:01 << wan#
13:00:02 >> ifconfig eth1
13:00:03 << inet addr:192.168.1.10
13:00:04 << link detected
13:00:05 << wan#

Here, the full interaction block is from line 1 to 5 easy.

2. Detect [prompt] [command] start

Using regex, look for:

  • << <prompt> record timestamp + mark as start

  • Next line: if starts with >>, it's a command

  • Gather all following << as response lines until next prompt or timeout/error

3. Build command-response segments

Each command block:

json
{
  "prompt": "wan#",
  "command": "ifconfig eth1",
  "response": ["inet addr:...", "link detected"],
  "terminated_by": "prompt" | "timeout" | "disconnect"
}

Core Logic (Pseudocode)

python
blocks = []
current_block = None

for line in lines:
    if is_prompt(line):
        if current_block:
            # finish previous block
            current_block["terminated_by"] = "prompt"
            blocks.append(current_block)
            current_block = None
        last_prompt = extract_prompt(line)
    
    elif line.startswith(">>"):
        current_block = {
            "prompt": last_prompt,
            "command": extract_command(line),
            "response": []
        }

    elif line.startswith("<<") or looks_like_output(line):
        if current_block:
            current_block["response"].append(line)

    elif "TIMEOUT" in line or "disconnect" in line.lower():
        if current_block:
            current_block["terminated_by"] = "timeout"
            blocks.append(current_block)
            current_block = None

Case 1: Prompt after command

plaintext
13:00:01 << wan#
13:00:02 >> ifconfig eth1
13:00:03 << inet addr...
13:00:04 << link detected
13:00:05 << wan#   prompt again

This gets captured correctly. Your segment is:

json
{
  "prompt": "wan#",
  "command": "ifconfig eth1",
  "response": ["inet addr...", "link detected"],
  "terminated_by": "prompt"
}

Case 2: No Output, Prompt Repeats

plaintext
13:10:01 << wan#
13:10:02 >> reboot
13:10:10 << wan#

Even if no << output lines in between, you still detect:

json
{
  "command": "reboot",
  "response": [],
  "terminated_by": "prompt"
}

If output is truly missing, that's an anomaly you can flag:

  • "response_lines": 0

  • "response_missing": true

Case 3: Timeout

plaintext
13:20:01 << wan#
13:20:02 >> tcpdump -n -i eth1
13:20:10 << (no output)
13:20:30 << TIMEOUT

Output:

json
{
  "command": "tcpdump -n -i eth1",
  "response": [],
  "terminated_by": "timeout"
}

This can go into your device_context:

json
"last_command": "tcpdump -n -i eth1",
"status": "timeout",
"last_response": null

Extra Heuristics (to improve quality)

  • Detect if same prompt repeats with no command "idle prompt"

  • Add timestamps delta between command & response large gap likely slow/failure

  • Mark "no response within N lines" as degraded

Output Example (log chunk)

json
"log_story": [
  {
    "source": "wan_console",
    "label": "Last command before failure",
    "snippet": [
      "13:20:01 << wan#",
      "13:20:02 >> tcpdump -n -i eth1",
      "13:20:30 << TIMEOUT"
    ]
  }
]

Summary: Answering Your Original Points

Your concernSolution
Prompt after command causes reverse scan issues Use forward scan, detect command block from prompt to prompt
No output, or partial output Treat as edge cases with terminated_by: timeout
Want clean extraction of relevant device logs Track each prompt-command block as unit, collect window around it for log_story
Some devices noisy Ignore unstructured noise lines that arent >> or <<, or dont match prompt regex

what about unessary garbagevalues or junk debug text taht miht appear in between consoles ?
ChatGPT said:

Great follow-up you're absolutely right to bring this up.

Problem: Junk / Noise / Garbage Text in Logs

Real-world console logs often look like this:

csharp
13:01:01 << wan#
13:01:02 >> ping 192.168.1.1
[DEBUG] entering command mode...
>>> START STATE MACHINE <<<
13:01:03 << Request timed out
[WARNING] No response within timeout
some unknown hex: 0xDEADBEEF
13:01:04 << wan#

This junk is:

  • From libraries, middleware, debug prints

  • Not part of the actual device input/output

  • May pollute your log segmenting or confuse ML/RCA

Solutions to Handle Noise Logs

1. Use Structured Regex Anchors (<<, >>, prompts)

Only treat lines with clearly prefixed markers as command or response:

  • >> = command

  • << = response

  • << prompt# = prompt

Other lines? Assume they're noise, unless you whitelist them.

2. Noise Filtering Rules

Create a small classifier or heuristic-based filter:

  • If a line matches debug/warning patterns:

    • ^\[DEBUG\], ^\[WARNING\], ^\[INFO\]

    • Lines with ONLY hex: 0x[A-Fa-f0-9]+

    • Known library/system logs (e.g. pexpect, pexec, etc.)

Mark those lines with:

python
is_noise = True

And either:

  • Skip them completely

  • Or keep them under "non_command_output" field if you want full traceability

3. Annotate Clean Blocks Only

Build command_blocks like:

json
{
  "prompt": "wan#",
  "command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
  "response": [
    "Request timed out"
  ],
  "noise_lines": [
    "[DEBUG] entering command mode...",
    "[WARNING] No response within timeout",
    "0xDEADBEEF"
  ],
  "terminated_by": "prompt"
}

So the downstream AI/human sees only meaningful data, while still retaining noisy context if needed.

4. Use Log Purification Pre-Processor (Optional)

If your system is extremely noisy, you can create a lightweight log purifier:

python
def purify_logs(lines):
    cleaned = []
    for line in lines:
        if is_known_noise(line):
            continue
        cleaned.append(line)
    return cleaned

Example (Before/After Purification)

Raw log:

csharp
13:01:01 << wan#
13:01:02 >> ping 192.168.1.1
[DEBUG] entering command mode...
>>> START STATE MACHINE <<<
13:01:03 << Request timed out
[WARNING] No response within timeout
some unknown hex: 0xDEADBEEF
13:01:04 << wan#

After segmentation:

json
{
  "command": "ping 192.168.1.1",
  "prompt": "wan#",
  "response": ["Request timed out"],
  "noise_lines": [
    "[DEBUG] entering command mode...",
    "[WARNING] No response within timeout",
    "0xDEADBEEF"
  ],
  "terminated_by": "prompt"
}

Final Note

If your logs are very unpredictable, adding a confidence score per extracted segment helps flag:

  • Incomplete outputs

  • Noise-heavy blocks

  • Suspect interactions
